wikipedia_page.main: Richard Bisset Halliwell (30 November 1842 – 9 November 1881) was an English first-class cricketer active 1865–73 who played for Middlesex. He was born in Bloomsbury and died in St Pancras, London. He played in 43 first-class matches as a righthanded batsman, scoring 502 runs with a highest score of 38*; and as a wicketkeeper, holding 35 catches and completing 41 stumped. He was the father of South Africa's captain and wicketkeeper Ernest Halliwell.

response: Ernest Halliwell was born on 7 September 1864 in Ealing, Middlesex, the son of Richard Halliwell, who was a wicket-keeper for Middlesex County Cricket Club. Though he played cricket as a boy in England, his debut in notable cricket occurred when Walter Read led a touring English side around South Africa. Haliwell appeared as wicket-keeper for South Africa in a match which was retroactively granted Test cricket status. He rose to prominence two years later, when a South African team toured the British Isles. Halliwell's wicket-keeping was judged by his English peers as being among the best in the world, and he was compared in equal terms with Jack Blackham and Gregor MacGregor, the Australian and English Test wicket-keepers of the time.
